results.title: Soil erosion
results.creator_credit: Information Films of India, Ezra Mir and Kenneth Villiers
results.brief_description: India has suffered as much as any other agricultural country from the devastation of soil erosion. This film gives a vivid account of the effects of soil erosion on village life, and shows clearly the dangers of uncontrolled erosion. The Forestry Department of the Indian government is applying various methods to combat erosion.

results.title: Soil conservation for the Snowy Mountains Scheme
results.creator_credit: Snowy Mountains Authority and H Malcolm
results.brief_description: Shows what has been done, by planting grasses, shrubs and trees, to combat soil erosion and cover scarred surfaces which have been left by road-making in the Snowy Mountains Scheme.

results.title: Soil Conservation District: Jerramungup
results.creator_credit: Western Australia. Dept. of Agriculture and Gerry North
results.brief_description: Describes how each committee member deals with a land degredation problem. Problems discussed and projects undertaken: wind erosion, tree and saltbush planting, direct drilling research, reduction of salinity and waterlogging in catchment area, growing of lucerne to reduce saline watertable.

results.title: Soil and water: a living world
results.creator_credit: Barr Films, Sandler Institutional Films, Greg Logan and Greg Johnson
results.brief_description: Four children are guided on a scientific adventure looking at the living world of soil and water. Explains how topsoil and water are full of plant and animal life called organisms. Indicates types of activities that can be carried out with these two common natural substances.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barr Films, Sandler Institutional Films, Greg Logan and Greg Johnson

results.title: Softball for girls
results.brief_description: Takes up the fundamental softball skills of throwing, catching, batting and fielding as they apply during the last inning of a girl’s intramural game. Each player’s individual skill and coordinated team play is pointed out.

results.title: Soft hands = El Aydi el naema
results.creator_credit: General Company for Arabic Film Production and Mahmoud Zulfikar
results.brief_description: Romantic comedy starring Sabah, one of the Middle East’s most popular singers of the 50’s - 70’s. Following the Egyptian revolution, Prince Chawkat resides in his palace, desperately trying to avoid destitution. As he tries to manage his domestic finances, his debts mount, forcing his family to make ends meet. Prince Chawkat must learn to earn his own living rather than rely on his inheritance. His daughters Jihan and Myrva try to assist him, but his pride constantly intervenes. When the Prince falls in love with a young woman, played by Sabah, he finds that he must learn humility before he can earn her love. Prince Chawkat’s journey reflects the message of Nasser’s ‘New Egypt’, creating its own opportunities and relying on its own resources rather than looking towards Europe for economic harmony. The film promotes that a man can create a destiny that culminates in a harmonious marriage and family life, through study and hard work. Sabah sings Houb al Khatf (Secret Love) and Beh Fatha Ba.

results.title: Soft fruit
results.creator_credit: Film Finance Corporation Australia, Fox Searchlight Pictures, Helen Bowden and Christina Andreef
results.brief_description: An estranged and dysfunctional family are reunited when the matriarch of the clan is diagnosed with terminal cancer. Patsy is a stoic figure, keeping the family united, despite their fractured relationships. Patsy’s eldest daughter is a nurse, caring for her ailing mother; her other two daughters travel from Sydney and abroad with their respective children. Their brother, Bo, a biker with a history of drug abuse, is out of jail on special leave and has been disowned by his disapproving father. Vic, their father, is a disgruntled, violent figure who treats his children with disdain, whilst resenting their rallying around Patsy. The narrative is devoted to reconciliation between the disparate family members, in particular the relationship between father and son. In the spirit of black and bleak comedy, Christine Andreef’s debut feature is reminiscent of early Jane Campion work, in particular “Sweetie”; indeed “Soft fruit” has many of the hallmarks of that quirky Australian comedy. Contains scenes of great poignancy and humour, despite a certain unevenness in tenor. Cast includes Jeanie Drynan, Linal Haft, Russell Dykstra, Genevieve Lemon, Sacha Horler and Alicia Talbot.

results.title: Sodium vapor (including Constellation and Oracle)
results.creator_credit: Bill Viola and TV Lab at WNET/Thirteen
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Writes Viola: `Sodium Vapor was recorded over a period of several weeks in the hours between one and five in the morning on the streets of an industrial area in lower Manhattan. The title derives from an interest in the particular qualities of sodium vapor street lighting — its characteristic color temperature, the shadows it casts, and the eerie quality it seems to impart to the objects it illuminates. The essence of the work is the spell which the hour has over the physical spaces of the streets in the early morning. There is always the unseen presence of the large number of people surrounding you, most of them sleeping; the camera is awake in their dreamtime. The recording of these locations in the middle of the night rather than in daylight represents a transformation — like figure/ground reversal — of these physical spaces from the familiar thoughts and activities of the day to the night time shadows of emptiness and obscurity.’
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Viola and TV Lab at WNET/Thirteen
